title: On champions with a dash-to-ally abilities...
body:
...can we maybe give them a briefly-visible dash range circle when they try to dash without selecting a target? Like, when they try to dash and nobody's in range, can it briefly show teammates the range radius?

I feel like this would drastically reduce situations where you're playing say, Lee Sin, or Rakan, or Jax, and you're just saying "STOP, COME A BLOODY INCH CLOSER, OH MY GOD YOU CAN SAVE ME WITH ZERO EFFORT."

This reminds me what a dark place our world is, sometimes I wonder if people know wtf Braum's kit is.

From what I've seen, his ult appears to be on a randomized timer, like a less regular Gnar ult. I know this from the fact that every Braum I've seen seems to fire it off at random times, in frequently random directions.

> [{quoted}](name=Memelon,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Bb1hLrpy,comment-id=00020001000000000000000000000001000000000000,timestamp=2017-05-23T00:48:40.635+0000)
>
> Lee sin is op and will be gutted u refuse to accept that cuz u dont know how to play him and hide behind false pretense because of how insecure you are towards how bad you are at playing one of the most overpowered champions in league

You're going after him because he never played Lee Sin, and yet if he played Lee Sin I bet you would go after him too for trying to defend his "imbalanced" Champion.
Don't attack him based on whether he played Lee Sin or not. That's not how one argues. One argues by providing _valid evidence_.

His early Q damage needs to be reworked so that he MUST land auto attacks or something in order to get the full damage. Right now it is too easy to just land a q and get 200 damage. take half the q damage and add it to the next 3 basic attacks. That way he is a bit more risk for the overly high reward.

They'd have to buff the damage of the ability then overall since they're stalling out the damage.

Do you really want Lee to have more DPS?

i'm saying if it currently did 100/100 for both sides of his q, change it to 50/50 and then add 100 damage to his next 3 basic(100/3 = +33to each) attacks for 3s. That way his Q can't be used as an early game nuke. It should reward smart dives, not early 100-0 BS.
That would still lead to them buffing the damage, as you are turning the damage from an instant burst into a dps ability like mordekaiser's q.

The overall damage would remain the same, but strictly decrease how often it is available. Most lee sin players can land 1 q early game and then faceroll to 100-0 everyone and then dash away. A change like this would force lee sin to stick to his target for extended an extended duration in order to get what he has currently. It would help separate smart/skilled lee players, from crappy bandwagon fans that get to benefit with very little skill or knowledge.

I agree 100% with what you are saying, but if there is one thing we KNOW for a fact, is that riot's balance team knows nothing about actual balance. I'm saying champions should be actually fair and balanced, and you are highlighting riot's inability to do that because they, like many of their ignorant yes men, think that every champ should have their cake and eat it too. They need to have more abilities with significant detrimental effects, instead of just pseudo-risk factors that are irrelevant in 99% of games played. The best example of this is their excuses for how nidalee, blah blah blah, spear, blah blah risky to dive in...etc. Realistically she can just dive in and oneshot, then leap out. There is almost no risk, unless you really screw up mechanically. What I want to see is rito putting their money where there mouth is and actually creating risk factors for their more broken champs.

Alright let me try to rephrase this.

By turning a burst damage ability into a sustained damage ability, riot will want to buff its damage because it's application is harder.

For example, let's say they, oh I don't know, turn veigar's point and click q into a skillshot. They then buff it in some way to compensate for it being harder to use.

They're going to add a bonus to the q if they make it next 3 or even next 2 basic attacks (next 3 basic attacks goes against his passive) because that's just what they'd do. Riot believes Lee is mostly balanced (and I tend to agree with this even if I do find the man annoying) so anything that would make his kit clunkier to use effectively would need some compensation or number buffs.

Riot shouldn't add indicators to compensate for incompetence

> [{quoted}](name=VulDread,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Bb1hLrpy,comment-id=0011,timestamp=2017-05-23T01:30:49.699+0000)
>
> But that ends up cluttering the screen.
> 
> Riot shouldn't add indicators to compensate for incompetence

It's not incompetence if not everyone plays everyone single dash champion, thus having every single one of their cast ranges memorized. This is a stupid way to think, it's a very clean animation whenever Rakan sees it for just himself. Just a simple, thin circle that glows a tad like a halo. It's not that big of a deal. Just because it doesn't benefit YOU doesn't mean it wouldn't save countless deaths from happening in League games.
They don't need the specific cast range, it's just that people should know which champs have the ability to dash to allies, and to walk towards them.

I feel like you've missed the aspect of how this would _teach_ them which champions should have the ability to dash to allies.

Since, y'know.

People who haven't been playing the since ancient Egypt exist, and are actually the reason why the game isn't dead.

You don't need to be a old player to know about it.

You just need to be a knowledgeable player. Something that comes with games played, not just years played.

It's not teaching them. The indicator being proposed isn't magically removed at some certain level or rank as it is in Coop vs AI games with turret ranges. The indicator is always there, and unneeded for experienced players. 

Bad players should not need a crutch to lean on for their lack of knowledge. They're supposed to gain knowledge about those dash ranges through playing the game.

It's the opposite of teaching. Rather than learning about the range by being punished when the ally dies due to being out of range for their dash, they won't be punished at all. They won't learn about the dash range, they'll just only look for the indicator.

Y'want to use an argument that isn't "human beings are _soooooo_ stupid if you give them a tool that'll visualize distance then their learning center will just melt down and man human are so insignificant why haven't we wiped them out yet"?

I mean I know a lot of teachers hold the same opinion that people can't learn from learning tools, but that's fooling yourself into thinking that American education is based around teaching stuff.

It's not a learning tool.

The indicator isn't there for learning, it's there for clarity.
